Sir Philip Green has paid £363 million to settle the pension schemes of collapsed retailer BHS. 
Britain's pensions regulator confirmed it has agreed a cash settlement with Green to provide funding for a new independent pension scheme. 
It will give pensioners the option of the same starting pension as they were originally promised by BHS, and higher benefits than they would get from the Pension Protection Fund (PPF). 
The collapse of BHS a year after Sir Philip sold the business for £1 dumped 11,000 people out of work and left a further 13,000 facing cruel cuts to their pensions . 
Angry MPs voted unanimously last year to strip Sir Philip of his knighthood over his role. 
In the stormy Commons debate last October he was branded a “ billionaire spiv” and compared to 19th century megalomaniac Napoleon . 
But the vote was only symbolic - as the power to strip Sir Philip of his gong remains in the hands of Sir Jonathan’s committee. 
And in a letter to Labour MP frank Field last month he wrote: “As you know, the Government is taking the circumstances surrounding the collapse of BHS very seriously, including investigations by the Insolvency Service and the Independent Pensions Regulator. 
“I believe it will be important to ensure any consideration of Sir Philip’s case by the forfeiture committee should have the benefit of the findings of the independent inquiries into BHS by the relevant regulators. 
Sir Jonathan added the Commons vote ‘will be carefully considered’ by the committee when it finally comes to making a decision. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
